requirement_designation: First Year Seminar with Race & Ethnicity(*)
class_notes:
(Freshmen Only)
(Same as AMST 190 1)


This seminar considers how the concept of citizenship has changed throughout US history. - How do ideals of US citizenship compare with historical realities? - How have social groups organized and mobilized for more expansive and inclusive citizenship? - What are the effects of current extreme economic inequality upon citizenship and representative democracy? Topics include voting rights, immigration policy, nationalism, consumerism, social justice, global citizenship, and the 2024 election cycle. 
"This discussion-based seminar draws upon a variety of source materials including the writings of historians, primary documents, critical essays, video documentaries, music and art of social protest, and internet archival resources.""Readings include publications by Heather Cox Richardson, Linda Kerber, Jill Lepore, Frederick Douglass, Elizabeth Cohen, Maxine Hong Kingston, Martin Luther King Jr., Iris Marion Young, Juan Gonzalez, Claudio Saunt, Linda Greenhouse, Chantal Mouffe." 
"Students are graded on class participation, reading commentaries and occasional quizzes, a semester paper (often drawn from family histories of migration and citizenship) and a final presentation."
course_description: Introduces first-year students to the discipline of history, particularly historical sources and methods; aims to improve critical reading, analytical, and writing skills in small group discussion.
